<p  style="
"><a name="Introduction"><b><span style="mso-bidi-;
">Introduction</span></b></a><span style="
"><o:p></o:p></span>

This Open Content supplement presents
rules first seen in War of Ashes: Fate of Agaptus. They cover the
following:<span style="
"><o:p></o:p></span>

Equipment stunts<o:p></o:p>

Advanced
conflict rules designed to support (but not require) use of miniatures<o:p></o:p>

Magic based
on the blessings and curses of capricious gods<span style="font-size:
12.0pt;"><o:p></o:p></span>

Wondrous
artifacts from a lost civilization<span style="
"><o:p></o:p></span>

Expanded
  adventure creation mechanics<o:p></o:p>
  <p  style="
    text-autospace:
    none">Re-scaling a
    campaign that has been running for a while<span style="
  "><o:p></o:p></span>
  <p  style="
    mso-layout-grid-align:
    none;">Together
      they can be used to play a range of fantasy adventures, from old-school
      dungeon-delving with Fate rules to epics in the vein of the Odysseus's
    adventures. <span style="
  "><o:p></o:p></span>
  <p  style="
    mso-layout-grid-align:
    none;">These
      rules can be matched either with approaches as in <span style="font-variant:
      small-caps">War of Ashes: Fate of Agaptus or <span style="font-variant:
      small-caps">Fate Accelerated</span>, or with skills as in Fate Core or <span style="font-variant:
    small-caps">Atomic Robo RPG</span>. Throughout the text, we provide examples
  based on both. </span><span style="
"><o:p></o:p></span>
<p  style="page-break-before:always;
  "><a name="Stunts"><b><span style="mso-bidi-font-size:
    12.0pt;;">Stunts</span></b></a><o:p></o:p>
    <p  style="
      "><a name="Equipment_Stunts"><b style="mso-bidi-font-weight:
        normal">Equipment Stunts</b></a><span style="
      "><o:p></o:p></span>
      <p  style="
        mso-layout-grid-align:
        none;"><span style=";
          ">In a fight it can make a big difference
          whether you hold a sword, a two-handed battle axe, or a potato peeler, so we
          use some rules for equipment, particularly weapons and armor. </span><o:p></o:p>
          <p  style="
            mso-layout-grid-align:
            none;">A
              stunt can reflect specialized, high-quality, or exotic equipment that your
              character has access to that gives them a frequent edge over other characters.<o:p></o:p>
              <p  style="
                mso-layout-grid-align:
                none;">Your
                  character starts with one equipment stunt, which works like a normal stunt but
                  has a few additional options. If a piece of equipment is such an important part
                of your character, you may even want to name it.<span style="font-size:
              12.0pt;"><o:p></o:p></span>
              <p  style="
                mso-layout-grid-align:
                none;"><b>Basic Effects</b>: Equipment stunts can
              take a form similar to regular or innate stunts.<span style="font-size:
            12.0pt;"><o:p></o:p></span>
            <p  style="
              mso-layout-grid-align:
              none;">With
              skills: <span style="
            "><o:p></o:p></span>
            <p  style="
              mso-layout-grid-align:
              none;">Because
                I have <b>[describe item]</b>, I get +2
                when I <b>[pick one: attack, defend, create
                advantages, overcome]</b> with <b>[pick
                one: Fight, Shoot]</b> when <b>[describe a
              narrow circumstance]</b>.<span style="
            "><o:p></o:p></span>
            <p  style="
              mso-layout-grid-align:
              none;">or<o:p></o:p>
              <p  style="
                mso-layout-grid-align:
                none;">Because
                  I have <b>[describe item]</b>, I can
                  substitute my <b>[pick one: Fight, Shoot]</b>
                  skill for <b>[normally used skill]</b> when
                  I <b>[pick one: attack, defend, create
                  advantages, overcome]</b> when <b>[describe
                  a narrow circumstance]</b>.<o:p></o:p>
                  <p  style="
                    text-autospace:
                    none"><b><span style="
                    ">Stiletto</span></b><span style="
                    ">: Because I hide a nasty stiletto in my
                    boot-top, I get +2 to attacks with Fight when my opponent have their back to
                  me.</span><span style="
                &quot;Times New Roman&quot;"><o:p></o:p></span>
                <p  style="
                  text-autospace:
                  none"><b><span style="
                  ">Knight's Shield</span></b>: Because I have my
                  knight's shield, I get +2 to defend with Fight from opponents coming from my
                left.<span style="
              &quot;Times New Roman&quot;"><o:p></o:p></span>
              <p  style="
                text-autospace:
                none"><b><span style="
                ">Sword of Theseus</span></b>: Because I wield the
                ancient sword of the hero Theseus, I can use Fight instead of Provoke to create
                an advantage by intimidating my opponents when they have a clear view of the brandished
              sword.<span style="
            "><o:p></o:p></span>
            <p  style="
              mso-layout-grid-align:
              none;">With
              approaches: <span style="
            "><o:p></o:p></span>
            <p  style="
              mso-layout-grid-align:
              none;">Because
                I have <b>[describe item]</b>, I get +2
                when I <b>[pick one: Carefully, Cleverly,
                Flashily, Forcefully, Quickly, Sneakily]</b> <b style="mso-bidi-font-weight:
                normal">[pick one: attack, defend, create advantages, overcome]</b> when <b>[describe a narrow circumstance]</b>.<o:p></o:p>
                <p  style="
                  text-autospace:
                  none"><b><span style="
                  ">Two-Handed Battle Axe</span></b>: Because my trusty
                  two-handed battle axe has a mighty arc, I get a +2 when I Quickly attack from
                above (such as leaping off a building).<span style="
              "><o:p></o:p></span>
              <p  style="
                text-autospace:
                none"><b><span style="
                ">My Father's Helmet</span></b>: Because I have my
                father's helmet, I get a +2 bonus when I Flashily create an advantage by
                yelling a short encouragement to my troops on the battlefield.<o:p></o:p>
                <p  style="
                  text-autospace:
                  none"><b><span style="
                  ">Round Buckler</span></b><span style="font-size:
                  12.0pt;">: Because I have a round buckler, I get a
                  +2 when I Carefully defend when facing only one opponent.</span><o:p></o:p>
                  <p  style="
                    mso-layout-grid-align:
                    none;"><b>Weapon Combinations</b>: What if you are
                    specifically trained with sword and shield, or are a master of the two-sword
                    technique? Do you need to spend two stunts on the combination, one for each
                    hand? Not necessarily. You could attach a stunt to the combination itself,
                  using the same formula as above.<span style="
                "><o:p></o:p></span>
                <p  style="
                  text-autospace:
                  none"><b><span style="
                  ">Florentine Style</span></b>: Because I fight with
                  sword and dagger, I get +2 when I successfully make a Fight attack against an
                  opponent in single combat.<o:p></o:p>
                  <p  style="
                    text-autospace:
                    none"><b><span style="
                    ">Sword and Shield</span></b>: Because I have a sword
                    and shield, I get +2 when I Carefully defend against damage coming from my
                  off-side.<span style="
                "><o:p></o:p></span>
                <p  style="
                  mso-layout-grid-align:
                  none;"><b>Lethal Damage</b>: Lethal damage does not
                  deal stress points—it goes directly to consequences (more on this in <b>Advanced Conflict</b> below.) If you want
                  to have a weapon stunt that lets you do lethal damage instead of one of the
                basic effects, it must have the form of:<span style="
              "><o:p></o:p></span>
              <p  style="
                mso-layout-grid-align:
                none;">Because
                  I have <b>[weapon]</b>, once per session I
                  deal lethal damage when I make a <b>[pick
                one: Fight, Shoot]</b> attack successfully.<span style="
              "><o:p></o:p></span>
              <p  style="
                mso-layout-grid-align:
                none;">or<o:p></o:p>
                <p  style="
                  mso-layout-grid-align:
                  none;">Because
                    I have <b>[weapon]</b>, once per session I
                    deal lethal damage when I make a <b>[pick
                    one: Careful, Clever, Flashy, Forceful, Quick, Sneaky]</b> attack successfully.<o:p></o:p>
                    <p  style="
                      mso-layout-grid-align:
                      none;">See
                        <b>"Lethal Attacks"</b> for more.<o:p></o:p>
                        <p  style="
                          text-autospace:
                          none"><b><span style="
                          ">Damascus Steel Sword</span></b>: Because my damascus
                          blade holds a fine edge that can pierce armor, once per session I deal lethal
                        damage when I make a Fight attack successfully.<span style="font-size:
                      12.0pt;"><o:p></o:p></span>
                      <p  style="
                        text-autospace:
                        none"><b><span style="
                        ">Spiked Morningstar "Skullbreaker"</span></b>: Because my heavy
                        morningstar crushes my foes' bones, once per session I deal lethal damage when
                      I make a Forceful attack successfully.<span style="
                    "><o:p></o:p></span>
                    <p  style="
                      text-autospace:
                      none"><b><span style="
                      ">Poisoned Dagger</span></b>: Because I have a
                      hollow dagger with a poison reservoir, once per session I deal lethal damage
                    when I make a Sneaky attack successfully.<span style="
                  "><o:p></o:p></span>
                  <p  style="
                    mso-layout-grid-align:
                    none;"><b>Zones and Ranged Weapons</b>: An equipment stunt
                    could also be used to affect opponents in other zones, or affect an entire zone
                  with an attack.<span style="
                "><o:p></o:p></span>
                <p  style="
                  mso-layout-grid-align:
                  none;">Because
                    I have <b>[weapon with long reach or range]</b>
                    I can use <b>[pick one: Fight, Shoot]</b> to
                    attack, create advantage, or overcome in <b>[pick
                    one: my zone and adjacent zones, up to three zones away but not in my zone]</b>.<o:p></o:p>
                    <p  style="
                      mso-layout-grid-align:
                      none;">or<o:p></o:p>
                      <p  style="
                        mso-layout-grid-align:
                        none;">Because
                          I have <b>[weapon with long reach or range]</b>
                          I can <b>[pick one: Carefully, Cleverly,
                          Flashily, Forcefully, Quickly, Sneakily]</b> attack, create advantage, or
                          overcome in <b>[pick one: my zone and
                          adjacent zones, up to three zones away but not in my zone]</b>.<o:p></o:p>
                          <p  style="
                            mso-layout-grid-align:
                            none;">or<o:p></o:p>
                            <p  style="
                              mso-layout-grid-align:
                              none;">Because
                                I have <b>[a weapon that affects multiple
                                targets]</b>, once per session I can attack every opponent in <b>[pick one: my zone, an adjacent zone]</b>.<o:p></o:p>
                                <p  style="
                                  mso-layout-grid-align:
                                  none;">See
                                    also <b>"Zones and the Battlefield"</b> for
                                  more info about zones.<span style="
                                "><o:p></o:p></span>
                                <p  style="
                                  text-autospace:
                                  none"><b><span style="
                                  ">Hallberd</span></b><span style="
                                  ">: Because I whirl my hallberd with flair, I can
                                  use Fight to attack, create advantages, or overcome in my zone or an adjacent
                                zone.</span><span style="
                              &quot;Times New Roman&quot;"><o:p></o:p></span>
                              <p  style="
                                text-autospace:
                                none"><b><span style="
                                ">Bow and Arrow</span></b><span style="font-size:
                                12.0pt;">: Because I have a bow and arrow, I can
                                use Shoot to attack, create advantages, or overcome up to three zones away, but
                              not in my zone.</span><span style="
                            "><o:p></o:p></span>
                            <p  style="
                              text-autospace:
                              none"><b><span style="
                              ">Throwing Knives</span></b>: Because I wield
                              throwing knives, I can Quickly attack, create advantages, and overcome in my
                            zone and adjacent zones.<span style="
                          "><o:p></o:p></span>
                          <p  style="
                            text-autospace:
                            none"><b><span style="
                            ">Alchemical Bombs</span></b>: Because I create
                            volatile alchemical concoctions, once per session I can attack every opponent
                          in my zone.<span style="
                        "><o:p></o:p></span>
                        <p  style="
                          text-autospace:
                          none"><b><span style="
                          ">Heavy Shield</span></b><span style="font-size:
                          12.0pt;">: Because I have a heavy shield on my
                          right arm, I get +2 to Forcefully push an opponent into an adjacent zone.</span><o:p></o:p>
                          <p  style="
                            mso-layout-grid-align:
                            none;"><b>Equipment Stunts and
                            Weight</b>:
                            Equipment stunts can also add weight in conflicts. See <b style="mso-bidi-font-weight:
                            normal">"Stunts and Weight"</b> for more detail and examples.<o:p></o:p>
                            <p  style="
                              mso-layout-grid-align:
                              none;"><b>Repair and Replacement</b>: Damaged or lost stunt
                              equipment can be repaired in play, or replaced as a stunt transfer as part of
                              normal milestone advancement.<o:p></o:p>
                              <p  style="
                                "><a name="Stunts_and_Weight"><b style="mso-bidi-font-weight:
                                  normal">Stunts and Weight</b></a><span style="
                                "><o:p></o:p></span>
                                <p  style="
                                  mso-layout-grid-align:
                                  none;"><span style="
                                    ">Some stunts can also affect weight. They
                                    typically take the form of:</span><o:p></o:p>
                                    <p  style="
                                      mso-layout-grid-align:
                                      none;">When I use my <b>[talent, advantage, equipment,
                                        or riding beast]</b> in <b>[pick as
                                        appropriate: social, mental, physical, etc.]</b> conflict, my weight counts as
                                        2 in <b>[narrow circumstance]</b>.<o:p></o:p>
                                        <p  style="
                                          text-autospace:
                                          none"><b><span style="
                                          ">Battledress Armor</span></b><span style="
                                          ">: Because I wear my battledress, my weight counts as 2
                                        when defending against physical attacks.</span><span style="
                                      "><o:p></o:p></span>
                                      <p  style="
                                        text-autospace:
                                        none"><b><span style="
                                        ">Wolf Rider</span></b><span style="
                                        ">: When I ride my faithful dire wolf into battle, my weight
                                        counts as 2 in physical conflicts against opponents of individual weight 2 or
                                      less.</span><span style="
                                    &quot;Times New Roman&quot;"><o:p></o:p></span>
                                    <p  style="
                                      text-autospace:
                                      none"><b><span style="
                                      ">Princeling</span></b><span style="
                                      ">: Because I am a princeling by-blow of King Olaf, my
                                      weight counts as 2 in social conflicts involving Vikings.</span><o:p></o:p>
                                      <p  style="
                                        text-autospace:
                                        none"><b><span style="
                                        ">Barbaric Yawp</span></b><span style="
                                        ">: When I sound my barbaric yawp, my weight counts as 2 in
                                      the first round of physical conflicts.</span><span style="
                                    "><o:p></o:p></span>
                                    <p  style="
                                      text-autospace:
                                      none"><b><span style="
                                      ">Big-Ass Axe</span></b><span style="
                                      ">: Because I am a Giant Creature of Destruction that wields
                                      a Big-Ass Axe, in physical conflicts my weight counts as 4 when I charge into
                                      melee. (Takes two stunt slots, i.e., two points of refresh. An appropriate
                                    stunt if playing a cave troll, for instance).</span><span style="font-size:
                                  12.0pt;"><o:p></o:p></span>
                                  <p  style="
                                    mso-layout-grid-align:
                                    none;">The
                                      GM and player can decide at the table if this type of stunt would go into their
                                      equipment slot or not, if applicable. Is your Big-Ass Axe considered your only
                                    weapon, or do you have that and a great spear?<span style="font-size:
                                  12.0pt;"><o:p></o:p></span>
                                  <p  style="page-break-before:always;
                                    "><a name="Advanced_Conflict"><b><span style="mso-bidi-font-size:
                                      12.0pt;;">Advanced
                                      Conflict</span></b></a><o:p></o:p>
                                      <p  style="mso-layout-grid-align:
                                        none;"><span style="
                                          ">Conflicts are used to resolve situations
                                          where characters are trying to harm one another, whether morally (hurting
                                          feelings), socially (demolishing reputations), physically (coming to blows), or
                                          through some other means. It could mean physical harm (a sword fight, a magic
                                          duel, a good old fashioned bar brawl), but it could also be mental harm (a
                                          shouting match, a tough interrogation, a debate between scholars).</span><o:p></o:p>
                                          <p  style="mso-layout-grid-align:
                                            none;">Let's
                                              start with a quick overview of how advanced conflict unfolds, then we'll go
                                              into more detail showing you step-by-step how this plays out.<o:p></o:p>
                                              <p  style="mso-layout-grid-align:
                                                none;"><span style="
                                                "><o:p> </o:p></span>
                                                <p  style="mso-layout-grid-align:
                                                  none;"><b>Conflicts: The 30-Second Version</b><o:p></o:p>
                                                  <p  style="mso-layout-grid-align:
                                                    none;"><span style="
                                                      ">Set the scene.</span><o:p></o:p>
                                                      <p  style="mso-layout-grid-align:
                                                        none;">Determine
                                                        turn order.<span style="
                                                      "><o:p></o:p></span>
                                                      <p  style="mso-layout-grid-align:
                                                        none;">Optional:
                                                        Roar phase.<span style="
                                                      "><o:p></o:p></span>
                                                      <p  style="mso-layout-grid-align:
                                                        none;">Start
                                                        the first exchange:<span style="
                                                      "><o:p></o:p></span>
                                                      <p  style="mso-layout-grid-align:
                                                        none;"><span>     </span><o:p></o:p>
                                                        <p  style="mso-layout-grid-align:
                                                          none;"><span>     On your turn, take an
                                                        action.</span><span style="
                                                      "><o:p></o:p></span>
                                                      <p  style="mso-layout-grid-align:
                                                        none;"><span>     On other people's
                                                        turns, defend against or respond to their actions as necessary.</span><o:p></o:p>
                                                        <p  style="mso-layout-grid-align:
                                                          none;"><span>     At the end of
                                                          everyone's turn, start a new exchange or end the conflict.</span><o:p></o:p>
                                                          <p  style="mso-layout-grid-align:
                                                            none;"><span>     </span><o:p></o:p>
                                                            <p  style="mso-layout-grid-align:
                                                              none;"><span style="
                                                              "><o:p> </o:p></span>
                                                              <p  style="
                                                                "><a name="Setting_the_Scene"><b style="mso-bidi-font-weight:
                                                                  normal">Setting the Scene</b></a><span style="
                                                                "><o:p></o:p></span>
                                                                <p  style="
                                                                  mso-layout-grid-align:
                                                                  none;"><span style="
                                                                  ">Establish what</span>'s going on, where everyone is,
                                                                  and what the environment is like. Who is the opposition? The GM should write a
                                                                  couple of situation aspects on sticky notes or index cards and place them on
                                                                  the table. Players can suggest situation aspects, too.<o:p></o:p>
                                                                  <p  style="
                                                                    mso-layout-grid-align:
                                                                    none;">The
                                                                      GM also establishes <i>zones</i>,
                                                                      loosely defined areas that tell you where characters are. Rather than
                                                                      limiting—as many other games would—how far in measurement units you
                                                                      can get in one unit of time, or how far you can shoot, then applying penalties
                                                                      for local conditions like terrain or visibility, it skips the math and looks at
                                                                      local conditions to <i>then</i> establish
                                                                      how far you can move or shoot.<o:p></o:p>
                                                                      <p  style="
                                                                        mso-layout-grid-align:
                                                                        none;">This
                                                                          method is also part and parcel of <i>Fate</i>'s
                                                                          fractal nature, since it allows re-scaling; if you change the time unit, or the
                                                                          size of the map, or both, then naturally your zones are going to change too,
                                                                          while necessitating no change to the rules describing how things work.<o:p></o:p>
                                                                          <p  style="
                                                                            "><a name="Zones_and_the_Battlefield"><b style="mso-bidi-font-weight:
                                                                              normal">Zones and the Battlefield</b></a><span style="mso-bookmark:
                                                                              Zones_and_the_Battlefield"></span><o:p></o:p>
                                                                              <p  style="
                                                                                mso-layout-grid-align:
                                                                                none;"><span style="
                                                                                ">Even in physical conflict, zones aren</span>'t measured in yards in the
                                                                                fiction or inches on a map—they're much more abstract than that. Roughly
                                                                                speaking, if another combatant is close enough that you could take a few steps
                                                                                and attack them with a hand-to-hand weapon, like a spear, axe, or dagger,
                                                                                you're both in the same zone. In non-physical conflicts a zone might represent
                                                                                areas of political influence, a clan supporting one of their own, the various
                                                                                gods' attention, or groups of people you can talk to.<o:p></o:p>
                                                                                <p  style="
                                                                                  mso-layout-grid-align:
                                                                                  none;">You
                                                                                    can visually represent zones using a number of different means, such as a
                                                                                    series of connected squares drawn on a piece of paper, index cards arranged
                                                                                    together on the table, elaborate 3-D terrain tiles, or anything in between. The
                                                                                    only thing that really matters is that everyone has a clear idea of where the
                                                                                    zones begin and end and how their spaces relate to one another.<o:p></o:p>
                                                                                    <p  style="
                                                                                      mso-layout-grid-align:
                                                                                      none;"><b>Physical conflict</b>: Raiders are attacking the
                                                                                      characters in an old farm house. The kitchen is one zone, the bedroom another,
                                                                                      the front porch another, and the yard a fourth. Anyone in the same zone can
                                                                                      easily throw punches at each other. You can also carry the fight from one room
                                                                                    into another.<span style="
                                                                                  "><o:p></o:p></span>
                                                                                  <p  style="
                                                                                    "><a name="Zones_for_NonPhysical_Conflict"><b><span style="
                                                                                      &quot;Liberation Sans&quot;;">Zones for Non-Physical
                                                                                      Conflicts</span></b></a><o:p></o:p>
                                                                                      <p  style="
                                                                                        mso-layout-grid-align:
                                                                                        none;"><span style="
                                                                                        ">That</span><span style="
                                                                                        ">'s all nice and well for a battlefield, but what about
                                                                                        conflicts that don't involve coming to blows? How do you establish zones for a
                                                                                        social conflict (for example, about who will become the new leader of a scout
                                                                                        troop) or a mental one (for example, a debate between scholars of the Royal
                                                                                      Academy of Sciences)?</span><span style="
                                                                                    "><o:p></o:p></span>
                                                                                    <p  style="
                                                                                      mso-layout-grid-align:
                                                                                      none;">The
                                                                                        process is essentially the same, but the zones represent more abstract
                                                                                        divisions of the metaphorical ground the opponents are fighting over.<o:p></o:p>
                                                                                        <p  style="
                                                                                          mso-layout-grid-align:
                                                                                          none;"><b>Social conflict</b>: Jusipio and Meloria,
                                                                                          respectively members of the Architects' Guild and the Merchants' Guild,
                                                                                          disagree about what to do with the limited supply of stones excavated from a
                                                                                          quarry. Jusipio argues for a bridge across the river to ensure the new city's
                                                                                          communications, while Meloria wants to build a new granary to protect the food
                                                                                          reserves from barbarian incursions. The Architects' and Merchants' Guilds form
                                                                                          two zones, the city council a third in between them.<o:p></o:p>
                                                                                          <p  style="
                                                                                            "><a name="Zone_Aspects"><b style="mso-bidi-font-weight:
                                                                                              normal">Zone Aspects</b></a><o:p></o:p>
                                                                                              <p  style="
                                                                                                ">Of
                                                                                                  course, zones aren't merely abstract space—they're the very terrain of
                                                                                                  the battlefield. To that end, every zone can have a zone aspect that tells you
                                                                                                  what's in it. Unlike character aspects, zone aspects shouldn't be particularly
                                                                                                  nuanced. The simpler and more straightforward, the better. No matter what the
                                                                                                  terrain in the zone is like, it's going to be useful in some situations and a
                                                                                                  hindrance in others. An aspect that clearly communicates that in one or two
                                                                                                words is ideal.<span style="
                                                                                              "><o:p></o:p></span>
                                                                                              <p  style="
                                                                                                mso-layout-grid-align:
                                                                                                none;"><span style="
                                                                                                ">Keep it intuitive and broad</span>—and short enough that it
                                                                                                can easily fit on an index card. There are two good reasons for this rule of
                                                                                                thumb. One, the battlefield is likely going to contain several zones and
                                                                                                therefore several aspects, and you don't want things to look cluttered and
                                                                                                confusing for the players or yourself. Two, time spent crafting the perfect
                                                                                                zone aspect is time not spent actually playing the game. Better a good zone
                                                                                              aspect now than a great one in 90 seconds.<span style="
                                                                                            "><o:p></o:p></span>
                                                                                            <p  style="
                                                                                              mso-layout-grid-align:
                                                                                              none;">A
                                                                                                zone might have <b><i style="mso-bidi-font-style:
                                                                                                normal">Trees</i></b> or a <b><i>Steep Slope</i></b>, or it might be a <b><i>Kitchen</i></b>
                                                                                                or a <b><i>Crumbling
                                                                                                Stairway</i></b>, or even a <b><i>Waterfall</i></b> or <b style="mso-bidi-font-weight:
                                                                                                normal"><i>Bottomless Chasm</i></b>. Every
                                                                                                zone needs a zone aspect. That flat, featureless meadow over there? Why, that's
                                                                                                an <b><i>Open
                                                                                              Field</i></b>.<span style="
                                                                                            "><o:p></o:p></span>
                                                                                            <p  style="
                                                                                              mso-layout-grid-align:
                                                                                              none;">If
                                                                                                a zone has more than one potentially interesting feature, either combine the
                                                                                                two into one succinct aspect (like a <b><i>Farmhouse On Fire</i></b>) or pick the one
                                                                                                that you think will be most entertaining or relevant to the scene and go with
                                                                                                that (what feels more fun for this combat, a <b style="mso-bidi-font-weight:
                                                                                                normal"><i>Narrow Passage</i></b> or all
                                                                                                those <b><i style="mso-bidi-font-style:
                                                                                              normal">Rocks and Boulders</i></b> in it?).<span style="
                                                                                            "><o:p></o:p></span>
                                                                                            <p  style="
                                                                                              mso-layout-grid-align:
                                                                                              none;">Normally
                                                                                                it's the GM's job to assign zone aspects, but that doesn't mean they all have
                                                                                                to be done in advance. If the PCs are in a starting position that prohibits
                                                                                                them from seeing the entire battlefield—due to a closed door, outcropping
                                                                                                of rock, heavy fog, or the like, feel free to leave them blank and fill them in
                                                                                              as the PCs gain visibility to them.<span style="
                                                                                            "><o:p></o:p></span>
                                                                                            <p  style="
                                                                                              mso-layout-grid-align:
                                                                                              none;">Alternately,
                                                                                                let the players define some of these aspects by exploring these zones. Handling
                                                                                                zone aspects in this way gives the players more control over their situation
                                                                                                and lends a little more unpredictability to the combat. This is a create an
                                                                                                advantage action, typically using Clever or Careful, and can be done from
                                                                                                another zone, provided the character in question can see into the unexplored
                                                                                                zone. Generally speaking, you can't replace an existing zone aspect, unless the
                                                                                                aspect itself is responsible for obscuring the zone in the first place. The
                                                                                                difficulty for this task should be fairly low, such as Average (+1) or Fair
                                                                                                (+2). If it makes sense that a zone aspect would make the task more difficult,
                                                                                                increase it by +2 for every such aspect. Likewise, if the unexplored aspect is
                                                                                                more than one zone away from the character, increase the difficulty by +2 for
                                                                                                every zone that separates them.<o:p></o:p>
                                                                                                <p  style="
                                                                                                  mso-layout-grid-align:
                                                                                                  none;">Olivia
                                                                                                    the scout wants to know what's hiding in the <b style="mso-bidi-font-weight:
                                                                                                    normal"><i>Fog</i></b> a couple zones over,
                                                                                                    so she takes time to Carefully peer into it and see what she can make out. The
                                                                                                    GM sets the difficulty at Average (+1), then bumps it up by +2 because of that <b><i>Fog</i></b>
                                                                                                    and another +2 for being two zones away. That doesn't sound so good to Olivia's
                                                                                                    player. Fortunately, she's able to move a zone closer, lowering the difficulty
                                                                                                    to Good (+3), and gets a result of Great (+4). Success! Since the scene takes
                                                                                                    place in a mountain pass, the player suggests that the zone actually contains a
                                                                                                    <b><i>Fog-Shrouded
                                                                                                    Chasm</i></b>, and the GM agrees. Someone's in for a surprise.<o:p></o:p>
                                                                                                    <p  style="
                                                                                                      mso-layout-grid-align:
                                                                                                      none;">Each
                                                                                                        pre-defined zone aspect starts the scene with one free invocation. Aspects
                                                                                                        "discovered" by the players (that is, by creating an advantage) start with one
                                                                                                      or two free invocations, as usual.<span style="
                                                                                                    "><o:p></o:p></span>
                                                                                                    <p  style="
                                                                                                      mso-layout-grid-align:
                                                                                                      none;">GMs
                                                                                                        are encouraged to use common sense when determining whether an aspect would
                                                                                                        affect a particular creature or character. For example, flying creatures would
                                                                                                        be affected by <b><i style="mso-bidi-font-style:
                                                                                                        normal">Buffeting Winds</i></b> but not by <b><i>Icy Ground</i></b>, and a swamp-dwelling
                                                                                                        creature would not mind <b><i>Marshy Terrain</i></b> but would be at a
                                                                                                        disadvantage on <b><i style="mso-bidi-font-style:
                                                                                                      normal">High Rocky Ground</i></b>.<span style="
                                                                                                    "><o:p></o:p></span>
                                                                                                    <p  style="margin-bottom:
                                                                                                      6.0pt;
                                                                                                      "><a name="Number_of_Zones"><b style="mso-bidi-font-weight:
                                                                                                        normal">Number of Zones</b></a><o:p></o:p>
                                                                                                        <p  style="
                                                                                                          "><span style="
                                                                                                          ">Deciding the size of a battlefield</span>—how many zones it
                                                                                                          contains—can be a tricky business. Too many and you have wasted space, or
                                                                                                          combatants spread so far apart that their spatial relationships to one another
                                                                                                          have little meaning. Too few, and everyone's crammed together into a too-small
                                                                                                          space, without a variety of terrain types to make things fun and interesting.<o:p></o:p>
                                                                                                          <p  style="
                                                                                                            mso-layout-grid-align:
                                                                                                            none;"><span style="
                                                                                                              ">Start by visualizing the scene in your
                                                                                                            mind</span>'s eye. What does
                                                                                                            the surrounding area look like? Is it all on a flat plain, or is there varying
                                                                                                            elevation? What's of interest nearby? If the answer comes back "Uh� I dunno."
                                                                                                            then put something interesting in and expand outward from there.<o:p></o:p>
                                                                                                            <p  style="
                                                                                                              mso-layout-grid-align:
                                                                                                              none;">In
                                                                                                                the course of their quest, Olivia, Rolf, and Deliah and some hired mercenaries
                                                                                                                need to deal with a hostile lizardmen encampment. The GM wants the scene to
                                                                                                                take place in a tactically interesting location, but other than knowing that
                                                                                                                she wants the PCs to have to take care of some guards, she isn't sure where to
                                                                                                                start. Fighting guards in a flat plain would be pretty dull, and she can't
                                                                                                                imagine the lizardmen would camp in such a vulnerable location anyway. Maybe
                                                                                                                they're in some badlands where they can post lookouts on natural pillars of
                                                                                                                rock—it's a cool visual. Even better would be access via a narrow ravine
                                                                                                                cutting through a low cliffside. So far the battlefield looks like this:<o:p></o:p>
                                                                                                                <p  style="
                                                                                                                  mso-layout-grid-align:
                                                                                                                  none;">At
                                                                                                                    the bottom of the cliff, our GM pictures a sparsely forested area with a
                                                                                                                    clearing—so the lookouts can see intruders coming---but also a water
                                                                                                                    feature of some kind, just to mix things up. A lake would be good. It's fun to
                                                                                                                    throw people into, and it makes some sense with the ravine. And a waterfall
                                                                                                                    flowing into it. Sure. You don't to be a professional geologist; we just want a
                                                                                                                  battlefield with interesting features.<span style="
                                                                                                                "><o:p></o:p></span>
                                                                                                                <p  style="
                                                                                                                  mso-layout-grid-align:
                                                                                                                  none;">That
                                                                                                                    seems like enough for some variety, with enough space that missile weapons will
                                                                                                                    make a difference. Our GM imagines hidden lizardmen archers on the clifftops
                                                                                                                    letting fly at the approaching PCs, a PC or two sniping back from cover of the
                                                                                                                    trees, someone being pushed into the lake, or maybe even off the waterfall or a
                                                                                                                  big jagged pillar�<span style="
                                                                                                                "><o:p></o:p></span>
                                                                                                                <p  style="
                                                                                                                  mso-layout-grid-align:
                                                                                                                  none;">Note
                                                                                                                    that our GM hasn't assigned aspects to two zones. She figures the PCs can't see
                                                                                                                    them from where they're starting (the <b><i>Sparse Trees</i></b> in the upper left),
                                                                                                                  plus it'll be fun to define them during play.<span style="font-size:
                                                                                                                12.0pt;"><o:p></o:p></span>
                                                                                                                <p  style="
                                                                                                                  "><a name="Determine_Turn_Order"><b style="mso-bidi-font-weight:
                                                                                                                    normal">Determine Turn
                                                                                                                      Order</b></a><o:p></o:p>
                                                                                                                      <p  style="
                                                                                                                        mso-layout-grid-align:
                                                                                                                        none;"><span style="
                                                                                                                          ">Your turn order in a conflict is based on
                                                                                                                          your approaches. In a physical conflict, compare your Quick approach to the
                                                                                                                        other participants</span>'—the
                                                                                                                        one with the fastest reflexes goes first. In a mental conflict, compare your
                                                                                                                        Careful approach—attention to detail will warn you of danger. Whoever has
                                                                                                                        the highest approach goes first, and then everyone else goes in descending
                                                                                                                      order.<span style="
                                                                                                                    "><o:p></o:p></span>
                                                                                                                    <p  style="
                                                                                                                      mso-layout-grid-align:
                                                                                                                      none;">Break
                                                                                                                        ties in whatever manner makes sense, with the GM having the last word. For
                                                                                                                        example, in an open fight, Forceful might break ties. In an ambush, it might be
                                                                                                                        Sneaky. Of course, if the situation makes it clear who attacks first (such as
                                                                                                                        an ambush, a ritual, or some sort of asymmetrical situation) then the situation
                                                                                                                        should trump the approaches.<o:p></o:p>
                                                                                                                        <p  style="
                                                                                                                          mso-layout-grid-align:
                                                                                                                          none;">GMs,
                                                                                                                            it's simplest if you pick your most advantageous NPC to determine your place in
                                                                                                                            the turn order, and let all your NPCs go at that time. But if you have a good
                                                                                                                            reason to determine turn order individually for all your NPCs, go right ahead.<o:p></o:p>
                                                                                                                            <p  style="
                                                                                                                              "><a name="Roar_Phase"><b><span style="mso-bidi-;
                                                                                                                              mso-hansi-background:yellow;mso-highlight:yellow">Roar</span></b></a><b><span>
                                                                                                                              Phase</b></span><o:p></o:p>
                                                                                                                              <p  style="
                                                                                                                                mso-layout-grid-align:
                                                                                                                                none;"><span style="
                                                                                                                                  ">The Roar phase is a fun option if you</span>'re using approaches (as in War
                                                                                                                                of Ashes: Fate of Agaptus
                                                                                                                                or <span>Fate Accelerated) and your
                                                                                                                              setting lends itself to it. </span>At the start of conflicts, combatants can psych themselves up, call
                                                                                                                              out challenges to each other, cast rituals, jockey for position, etc.; this is
                                                                                                                              called the <span>Roar
                                                                                                                              phase, when opponents can enter a transcendent state.</span><o:p></o:p>
                                                                                                                              <p  style="
                                                                                                                                mso-layout-grid-align:
                                                                                                                                none;">This
                                                                                                                                  state may occur through intense concentration and focus, through wildly
                                                                                                                                  uncontrolled (and usually violent) emotions, through fearless derring-do, or
                                                                                                                                the like. <span style="
                                                                                                                              "><o:p></o:p></span>
                                                                                                                              <p  style="
                                                                                                                                mso-layout-grid-align:
                                                                                                                                none;">To
                                                                                                                                  Roar is to be a paragon of one chosen facet of oneself. To outside eyes, the
                                                                                                                                  studiously intense scholar would seem to have nothing in common with the
                                                                                                                                  literally-foaming-at-the-mouth barbarian warrior, but both are, in fact,
                                                                                                                                roaring.<span style="
                                                                                                                              "><o:p></o:p></span>
                                                                                                                              <p  style="
                                                                                                                                mso-layout-grid-align:
                                                                                                                                none;">In
                                                                                                                                  Fate terms, Roar is an initial step of conflict during which anyone can create
                                                                                                                                  an advantage. With great reward, however, comes great risk, and roaring means
                                                                                                                                  not having access to the full range of your usual capabilities.<o:p></o:p>
                                                                                                                                  <p  style="margin-bottom:
                                                                                                                                    6.0pt;
                                                                                                                                    "><a name="Creating_a_Froth_Aspect"><b style="mso-bidi-font-weight:
                                                                                                                                      normal">Creating a Roar Aspect</b></a><span style="mso-bookmark:
                                                                                                                                    Creating_a_Froth_Aspect"></span><span style="
                                                                                                                                  "><o:p></o:p></span>
                                                                                                                                  <p  style="
                                                                                                                                    mso-layout-grid-align:
                                                                                                                                    none;"><span style=";
                                                                                                                                      ">In one respect, creating a Roar aspect is
                                                                                                                                    like creating any other situational aspect</span><span style="
                                                                                                                                  ">—</span><span style="
                                                                                                                                  &quot;Liberation Mono&quot;">they're both just using an approach to create an advantage.
                                                                                                                                  But there are three major differences when it comes to actually bringing one of
                                                                                                                                  these aspect extras into being.</span><o:p></o:p>
                                                                                                                                  <p  style="
                                                                                                                                    mso-layout-grid-align:
                                                                                                                                    none;">For
                                                                                                                                      one, when you roar and as long as you are in this state, you are limited to
                                                                                                                                      using the approach you used to create the Roar advantage, and the two connected
                                                                                                                                      approaches (see the diagram).<o:p></o:p>
                                                                                                                                      <p  style="
                                                                                                                                        mso-layout-grid-align:
                                                                                                                                        none;">Olivia
                                                                                                                                          is entering a conflict with Lord Marcus Sidonius and Olivia's player wants her
                                                                                                                                          to roar with Careful, so she attempts to create the advantage <b><i>Intensely
                                                                                                                                          Focused</i></b>. Once she's roaring, she can use the free invoke from that
                                                                                                                                          aspect normally, but she's limited to the Careful, Sneaky, and Clever
                                                                                                                                        approaches.<span style="
                                                                                                                                      "><o:p></o:p></span>
                                                                                                                                      <p  style="
                                                                                                                                        mso-layout-grid-align:
                                                                                                                                        none;">Second,
                                                                                                                                          the base difficulty to create one of these Roar aspects is +2. The players and
                                                                                                                                        the GM take turns rolling for Roar aspects<span style="
                                                                                                                                      ">—</span><span style="
                                                                                                                                      &quot;Liberation Mono&quot;">that's right, the GM can create as many aspects as the
                                                                                                                                      players do. How many free invocations are generated for each aspect, however,
                                                                                                                                      depends on the roll results.</span><o:p></o:p>
                                                                                                                                      <p  style="
                                                                                                                                        mso-layout-grid-align:
                                                                                                                                        none;">Finally,
                                                                                                                                          trying and failing to create a Roar aspect means success at a cost. The Roar
                                                                                                                                          aspect will be created, but along with it will come a related consequence for
                                                                                                                                          the GM to use against the PC. On a tie, the GM only gets a boost against the PC
                                                                                                                                          rather than a consequence. It's a tricky business, transcending the bounds of
                                                                                                                                          mortal consciousness and capability. With great ambition comes great risk, and
